The second factor is Jin Ling, who casually mentions to his mother that his friends are visiting Lotus Pier. When it comes to light that one of the friends is the child of Han Guang-Jun, who will be traveling with them, the Jiang family decides to extend a personal invitation to their estate.
“I told them you guys can just book a hotel,” Jin Ling says three days before the start of the holidays. “But Laolao started yelling at me about how she owns all the hotels in Lotus Pier and that everything has been booked out for the holidays. She says it would personally offend her if you found accommodations elsewhere when there are perfectly good guest rooms at her place.”
Jingyi is counting his fingers. “Aren’t your family staying with them too? How many guest rooms do they have?”
Jin Ling looks as if someone has asked a very dumb questions about how many guest rooms the emperor’s palace has. “More than enough.”
“Huh.” Jingyi sets a heavy hand on Sizhui’s shoulder. “I guess we’re going to Yunmeng!”
On the Friday before National Week, Jingyi dashes out of his last morning class to grab his suitcase from the dorms, where Suzhui and Jin Ling are waiting for him with varying levels of patience. Jingyi commends himself on having the foresight to pack beforehand, even if Sizhui deserves most of the credit for gently needling Jingyi days in advance. Still, most of Jingyi’s travel belongings are safely packed in his luggage, neatness notwithstanding. “I’m ready!” Jingyi huffs when he finally joins the other boys.
“Better late than never,” Jin Ling mumbles. He looks even more overpacked than usual, clad in a overcoat that screamed I’m rich! 
“Father is waiting for us,” Sizhui adds. He’s too polite to rush them, but Jingyi knows him well enough to understand that’s code for we’re late. 
Together, the three of them lug their bags to the school gates toward the car Jin Ling had called for them. The ride to Shanghai West Station is long and tedious, and Jingyi recognizes the telltale signs for the great National Week migration as the roads are clogged even more so than normal. Thankfully, they arrive in time to go through baggage check and meet Lan Wangji at the gate.
“Sorry for our lateness.” Sizhui takes a seat next to Lan Wangji. He pauses at the stacked items next to them. “Father, what are these?”
“Gifts for the hosts,” Lan Wangji replies. His gaze lands on the box of sweets in Sizhui’s hands. “I see you brought some as well.”
“Jin Ling is the one who suggested it.” 
Sizhui leaves out the fact that Jingyi and Sizhui were the ones who had lined up for over an hour at the local traditional dessert shop while Jin Ling was busy at archery practice. In his defense, Jingyi had kept his mouth shut while the girl at the counter made heart eyes at Sizhui as she wrapped up their box. 
“My grandmother has very selective taste,” Jin Ling says, as if he hadn’t warned them a dozen times of his grandmother’s strictness. In no uncertain terms had Jin Ling told Jingyi to be on his best behavior. At this point, Jingyi fully expects to be meeting Empress Dowager Cixi at Lotus Pier. 
Even worse than the repeated prodding had been Jin Ling’s family tree, which he presented to Jingyi and Sizhui in the form of a powerpoint. Jin Ling had stressed the importance of memorizing his family members, lest they misstep and embarrass Jin Ling. Jingyi was pretty sure Jin Ling just recycled his family tree presentation from English class. Either way, his head was so filled to the brim with useless information about the Jin-Jiang family that Jingyi had accidentally written Jin Ling’s name by accident on his history quiz. 
Jingyi wonders if Jin Ling sent Lan Wangji the same slideshow. Probably not, considering how Jin Ling still seems in awe of Sizhui’s father. 
“Thank you for arranging accommodations for us,” Lan Wangji says, passive as always. He seems to be appraising Jin Ling, who straighten up under his gaze. 
“N-Not at all! My family insisted!”
They move to the boarding area soon after that. Shanghai West is the departure station for their high speed rail, and the station attendants let them board the business class cabin without fanfare. Jingyi is impressed by the extra leg room in their row, and soon turns their chairs around so all four seats face each other. The cabin is half empty, so no one complains about the noise.
Jin Ling is still on his phone when the train begins moving. “My mother is sending someone to pick us up from Yunmeng station. Most of my family is already at the estate.”
It must be nice to be rich, Jingyi thinks. His own parents have to work through the weekend before their break officially starts on Monday. Jingyi had only gotten away with his last-minute vacation plans due to Lan Wangji’s participation and his improved math grade. He continues nibbling on the sunflower seeds Sizhui packed. “What about your dog?”
“Fairy is traveling with Xiaojiu.” Jin Ling looks visibly excited at the mention of his dog. Behind him, sceneries flash through the window as the train picks up speed. “But my parents are taking him back to Lanling after this.”
“I’m excited to see Fairy again,” Sizhui offers. He turns to his father as if expecting Lan Wangji to contribute to the conversation with some farfetched declaration of being excited to see Wei Wuxian. This, of course, does not happen.
For the most part, Lan Wangji is blissfully quiet through the ride. He reads a novel silently while Jingyi cycles through a series of proposals to keep them busy. They play cards, a multiplayer game on Jin Ling’s iPad, and then cards again. Lan Wangji orders them late lunches when the cart ladies comes around with boxed meal, but leaves his own serving mostly untouched while the boys inhale their food. 
A few people onboard and offboard the cabin at the intermittent stops between Shanghai and Yunmeng. After a while, Jin Ling dozes off against the window while Jingyi watches the scenery change from urban snapshots to the wide expanse of the countryside. Just for fun, Jingyi snaps a photo of Jin Ling’s sleeping face with a dog filter and shows it to Sizhui.
“Behave,” Sizhui mouths silently, despite looking amused. 
The three hour ride ends unexpectedly fast, and soon Jingyi is shaking Jin Ling awake while Sizhui moves their luggages from the overhead compartments. “Wake up, Little Mistress! We need you to navigate us~”
Jin Ling manages to glare through sleepy eyes. Still, he leads them off the train and into the utter chaos that is Yunmeng station. “What?” Jin Ling asks when a family almost runs into him. “I told you this is a popular tourist destination.”
With utmost determination and a little bit of side stepping, they manage to make it out of the exit to find a sea of taxis and personal cars parked in the arrival area. Jin Ling immediately locates a man holding a purple sign and leads them to him.
“Welcome back, Young Master Jin.”
“Driver Li,” Jin Ling says importantly. “Take us to your vehicle.”
The vehicle turns out to be a luxury minivan. Jingyi bites the inside of his mouth as Driver Li loads all of their stuff into the trunk. He supposes this is better than cramming into a taxi, and tries his best to keep his mouth shut while climbing into the back row of the van. 
“We will arrive in forty minutes,” Drive Li tells them as they pull out of the station. “Please help yourself to snacks and beverages in the middle compartment.”
Jin Ling has the audacity to take the front passenger seat. While he asks Driver Li questions about traffic, Sizhui turns to his father.
“Have you visited Yunmeng before?”
Lan Wangji doesn’t turn his head from the window. “No,” he says almost wistfully.
The station is located in a rural part of Yunmeng, amidst vast fields of crops broken by tiny stone houses. Every so often, their van has to slow down to weave around small work vehicles and farmers pulling donkeys along. The main road follows the curvature of a large lake, the surface so wide and smooth that Jingyi can’t see where the water ends. But the scenery soon changes into something more commercialized, and farm houses are replaced with newly built villas. 
“This is lovely,” Sizhui says when the road begins expanding, and they see more visitors milling about. 
When they drive through a large stylized archway, Jin Ling turns to them and says, “Welcome to Lotus Pier. Well, this is only the outer edge. My grandparents’ estate is towards the other end.”
“The Jiang family home is famous for its architecture,” Driver Li explains as the car pulls off the main road and towards what appears to be a dock. “It’s surrounded by water, and visitors at Lotus Pier regard it as a signature landmark.”
“Why are we stopping here?” Jin Ling asks when Driver Li parks the vehicle. They’re currently at a dock that doubles as a viewing area, with other families parked nearby as they sit at picnic tables overlooking the water. 
Driver Li opens the door for Jin Ling. “The rest of the road is blocked by tourist traffic. It would take another hour for us to reach the estate. Madam Jiang has advised you to take the boat. We will part here.”
Jingyi looks around the pier. There are a few sailboats docked by the water, but what Driver Li leads to them to can only be described as a small yacht. “Are we taking this?”
While Driver Li diligently moves their luggage, another man appears from the inside of the boat. He’s round and tall and tan, and the hand he sets on Jin Ling’s shoulder is nothing short of friendly. “Young Master Jin! You’re so tall now! Do you remember me?”
“Wu-Shushu,” Jin Ling says, his nose high in the air. “Long time no see.”
“Lao Wu,” Driver Li cuts in. “Someone should be waiting for them at the West Port.”
“Got it, got it,” Lao Wu laughs as he gestures for Jingyi and Sizhui and Lan Wangji to come onboard. “I’ve been sailing this boat for Master Jiang for thirty years, and Driver Li still feels the need to remind me every time. I’m telling you-- I’ve been doing this since Mistress Yanli has been a child. Just because I took Master Jin to the wrong dock in the middle of the night once... Oh, Driver Li, stop giving me the stink eye! They’re in good hands!”
“You did that to my dad?” Jin Ling asks, mouth wide. “Why?”
Lao Wu waits until everyone has boarded to turn on the engine. “Why? Young Masters Jiang and Wei told me to, of course! They thought it would be a fun prank to ambush your father. Those boys have always been trouble makers, but no harm done, you see? Your parents are happily married, years later!”
“If you don’t mind me asking,” Sizhui says when Lao Wu is done laughing at his own story. “Where are we going?”
“The Jiang family has a private dock on the west end of their estate. Before the main roads were built, taking the boat was the fastest way of getting to the rest of Lotus Pier! We’ve been doing this for decades. My old man worked for Master Jiang’s father, and now I work for Master Jiang."
Jingyi squints as the boat starts to move. On the dock, a little girl is waving at them. Jingyi waves back. “What is this? Your grandparents have servants?”
“They’re staff, not servants!” Jin Ling huffs.
“Jingyi, don’t be rude,” Lan Wangji speaks up for the first time in an hour. 
Lao Wu just cackles some more. “No offense taken! There’s no better employer in Lotus Pier than Master Jiang! We almost got bought out by commercial realtors around thirty years ago. They wanted to drive all the locals out and fill this place with chains! But then the Jiang family stepped in and bought out the land so they can keep leasing to the locals. We used to just be a fishing port fifty years ago, and now look at us! Tourism keeps bringing money in! Business is good!”
“Sorry,” Jingyi mumbles after a bit. “Guess your grandparents are cool after all.”
Over the water, the Jiang estate appears like a vision. As the boat pulls closer, they’re greeted by patches of lotus almost floating on the water, as if parting a path just for them. Jingyi can make out the shape of a woman standing on the end of the wooden boardwalk, her long purple skirt swaying in the breeze. She’s flanked by identical small girls on each side.
“Mom!” Jin Ling gasps. He doesn’t wait for the boat to dock properly before jumping onto the wooden steps and enveloping his mother in a hug. 
“A-Ling,” Jiang Yanli laughs. “It’s nice to see you too!” Next to her, the girls tug on Jin Ling’s arms and legs and clothes, going Gege! Gege! Gege!.
Jin Ling is playing when the kids when Lao Wu finally secures the connection between the boat and the dock. Jin Ling looks sheepish, but not embarrassed. “Sorry, Han Guang-Jun. This is my mother.”
Lan Wangji gives Jiang Yanli a nod. “Thank you for your hospitality.”
“There’s no need to be so formal, Han Guang-Jun. I’m still indebted to your brother after all the help he’s given me. Not to mention how close Ze Wu-Jun is to A-Ling’s shushu. Our families are so close already, it’s an honor and a pleasure to have you here.” Coming from anyone else, her words may seem insincere or over-exaggerated. Yet there’s something calming and genuine about her voice that puts Jingyi at ease.
Eventually, Lan Wangji says. “The honor is ours. This is Lan Sizhui and Lan Jingyi.”
Jiang Yanli smiles directly at Jingyi. “I’ve heard so much about you two from A-Ling. It’s not everyday my son brings friends home.” 
“Mom!” Jin Ling yells, face red.
Jiang Yanli smiles even more, gesturing for the twins to come to her. “These are my daughters, Tiantian and Qianqian.”
“Where’s Dad?”
“He stayed behind to watch Fairy with Bingbing,” Jiang Yanli says, letting go of Qianqian’s hand when the child decides to cozy up to Sizhui. Tiantian, however, stays half hidden behind her mother. It would have been impossible to tell them apart if not for the introduction. “Remember, you promised to keep Fairy away from A-Xian.”
“Should I call you Lingling now?” Jingyi asks while Jiang Yanli speaks to Lao Wu. 
“Only if you want to die,” Jin Ling hisses. 
Two more staff members appear then, moving everyone’s luggage onto a rolling cart. They nod when Jiang Yanli asks them to take the bags to the East Wing, where the guests will be staying. 
“We are only operating at half capacity at the moment,” Jiang Yanli explains when they begin walking away from the water, towards the estate. “Most of the staff went home for the holidays. We even sent our nanny on vacation, so I hope you don’t mind the noise. Tiantian, what’s wrong?”
Tiantian is completely silently, gripping her mother’s hand while Qianiqan circles around Sizhui like he’s a fun new toy. “Up up,” she says quietly when everyone looks at her.
“What?” Jingyi asks.
“Up up,” Tiantian says again. “I want bao bao!”
“She wants to be picked up,” Jin Ling translates.
“We’re almost there,” Jiang Yanli tells her daughter. “Don’t you want to walk just like Qianqian and Gege?”
The desire to be just like her siblings seems to trump Tiantian’s need to be picked up, and she goes back to following her mother silently. They continue at a leisurely pace until the wooden boardwalk turns into a stone path through the gardens, the expanding walkway framed by poles with large purple lanterns hanging on top. In the distance, to their right, Jingyi spots smaller pond with a gazebo on top.
“That’s my mother’s favorite place to lounge,” Jiang Yanli explains when she catches Jingyi looking. “During the summertime, you can come out in the evenings to see fireflies on the waters. In fact, I think there’s a tree near the gazebo that A-Cheng and A-Xian used to mark their height on growing up.” 
At the mention of Wei Wuxian, Lan Wangji turns his head to the pond as well. 
Jiang Yanli just hums. “The garden was especially designed by my mother. It’s her pride and joy, and she severely punished my brothers when she discovered them carving into her favorite elm tree. Oh, we’re almost here.”
Sure enough, they soon arrive at a stone moon gate that connects the gardens to a courtyard. Waiting at the entrance are two people who look undeniably related to their little mistress.
At the sight of Jin Ling, Fairy jumps out of the teenage girl’s arm and comes bouncing along until he’s climbing up Jin Ling’s legs. Jin Ling picks him up immediately and laughs when Fairy licks his face in excitement. “Calm down, it’s just me!”
“Just you is enough. Welcome back, A-Ling,” Jin Zixuan says while Tiantian immediately latches onto him. Up close, Jingyi can see how Jin Ling shares the same haughty nose and curved mouth as his father. “Han Guang-Jun, long time no see.”
While Jin Zixuan and Lan Wangji exchange pleasantries, Qianqian pulls Sizhui’s arm down and loudly whispers, “that’s Daddy, he’s the best,” into Sizhui’s ear. 
“She loves strangers,” the person who has to be Jin Bing tells Jingyi. She’s almost his height and can probably pass for Jin Ling’s twin if not for the look of passive disinterest on her face as she listens to another round of introductions. The Jin genes really run strongly in this family, Jingyi thinks but doesn’t say.
“Let’s go in,” Jiang Yanli suggests after Fairy has calmed down. She gives Jin Ling a firm look that gets Jin Ling to quickly clip Fairy’s leash onto his collar. They’re led through a series of paths until arriving at a large, four-sided courtyard. Facing the north is an open-air hall. At the top of the steps sits a stern looking woman in a throne-like chair. Jiang Yanli smiles up at her. “A-Niang, our guests are here.”
Yu Ziyuan descends slowly down the steps until she’s looming over them. “Han Guang-Jun. Welcome to my home. My husband is taking care of some business with my son. Please excuse their absence.” Everything that comes out of her mouth sounds more like an order than a request.
“Thank you for having us,” Lan Wangji says, perhaps for the 10th time that day. He looks at Sizhui.
As if on cue, Sizhui steps forward. “Madam Yu, thank you for extending your hospitality to us. Please accept this box of sweets from Gusu’s famous dessert shop. They’re infused with chili, which Jin Ling told us may be to your liking. We also brought three jars of Emperor’s Smile from my great uncle’s collection, along with a box of fresh crystal loquats.”
Yu Ziyuan eyes offerings appraisingly. After an eternity, she says, “I didn’t know Lan Qiren had a taste for rice wine.”
“Uncle has an interest in collecting them,” Lan Wangji speaks up when Sizhui gets flustered under Yu Ziyan’s gaze. 
“Very well,” Yu Ziyuan says as she calls a staff member forward. “Have Chef Wang use the loquats in tonight’s meal. He knows how Jiang Fengmian likes it prepared. Serve the sweets for dessert. I’ll be the judge of whether A-Ling knows my taste.”
A small smile breaks across Jiang Yanli’s face, and Jingyi takes that as a sign Madam Yu has more or less accepted them. “Let’s set the Emperor’s Smile aside for tomorrow, when A-Xian arrives. He’ll be disappointed if we drink it all without him.”
“Yes, Madam.” The staffer accepts all the gifts and hurries away. 
“Han Guang-Jun,” Yu Ziyuan continues. “I have some thoughts about your brother’s contribution to the exhibition in Hangzhou. Since he’s not here, I hope you’ll indulge me and hear me out?” Again, her request is worded more like a demand, and Lan Wangji slowly goes to her side. “Let’s walk and talk while the children settle in. A-Li, help everyone to their quarters, won’t you?” 
“Of course,” Jiang Yanli says, but Madam Yu is already off, commanding Lan Wangji to follow.
Everyone waits until they’re both out of sight to relax. Jingyi nudges Sizhui. “Your face was so red! It’s like you forgot to breathe!”
“She has that effect on people,” Jin Ling says, sympathetic. Even Fairy has stayed on his best behavior. 
“Can I go now?” Jin Bing asks, looking bored by it all. Upon getting a nod of approval from Jiang Yanli, she disappears around the corner, presumably back to her room. “Come, Fairy!”
Jin Ling looks betrayed when his dog goes bouncing after his sister happily.
“Don’t be upset,” Jiang Yanli laughs softly. “You haven’t been home in so long, and Bingbing usually takes care of Fairy when you’re gone. Although A-Cheng definitely spoiled him for the last few weeks.”
As if following Jin Bing’s lead, one of the twins tugs on Jin Zixuan’s hand. “I wanna go too… I’m tired..” 
“It’s about that time. ” Jiang Yanli sets a hand on her husband’s arm. “Can you put them down for a nap? You remember where I left their bag, right? Qianqian’s blanket is still in our room.”
“Of course,” Jin Zixuan says, looking more amused than annoyed. “I can do this much.”
As if to prove her dad otherwise, the twin currently standing next to Jin Ling starts complaining. “I don’t want to nap! I want to play with Gege!”
“Gege is busy with Lan-gege,” Jiang Yanli replies, trying to hide her laughter at the sight of Jin Zixuan’s astonished face. “He’ll have time for you after your nap, Qianqian.”
“I want to play with Lan-Gege!” Qianqian stumps her little leg on the ground. “I’ll show him the entire house! I’ll be the host!”
“You don’t even know the layout of the entire house,” Jin Zixuan says. When Qianqian looks offended at his suggestion and her face turns red, on the precipice of tears, Jin Zixuan adds, “Can you relax?”
The only thing funnier than Jin Zixuan asking a four year old to relax is the look of betrayal on Jin Ling’s face at the suggestion that his sister likes Sizhui more than him. 
“I’m feeling a little tired too,” Sizhui suggests when Qianqian is on the verge of a fit. “Let’s both take naps. Then we can play when we’re both energized. How about that? I’ll be here for the week. We have plenty of time to play. You can show me the rest of the house too.”
Qianqian considers this for a moment. “okay.” 
It’s not until Jin Ling’s parents have led the twins away that Jingyi bursts out laughing. Jin Ling’s glare doesn’t help, and Jingyi is wiping tears of mirth from his eyes when Jin Ling leads them to the East Wing, where their luggage is already waiting. Sizhui and Jingyi have been assigned to connected rooms, the layout reminiscent of a traditional guesthouse. “This place is humongous,” Jingyi says after testing the bed. It’s firm but comfortable. “Your grandparents are crazy rich.”
Jin Ling gives him a funny look. “Our property in Lanling is even bigger.”
“Of course it is.” Jingyi flops with his back down on the bed. “Don’t forget though, we’re here for business, not pleasure.”
This makes Jin Ling tsk. “Stop acting like we’re here on a secret mission. How difficult can it be to set two old men up?”
Jingyi says “pretty difficult” the same time Sizhui says “I wouldn’t call them old.” 
“What is your plan anyway? Are you going to lock them in the same room?” Jin Ling takes a seat on the bed and slap absently at Jingyi’s leg.
“Love needs to blossom naturally!” Jingyi huffs. “Being locked in a dark room isn’t romantic! We need ambience! We need the mood to be perfect. We need Han Guang-Jun to look up at Wei Wuxian, bathed in moonlight, and he realize he’s fallen in love!”
“What you need is to stop. You’re almost bad as Bingbing. All she does is stay in her room reading internet novels and talking to her online friends!”
Jingyi promptly sits up. “Oh… I wonder which one she’s reading? Maybe she can give me recommendations.” When Jin Ling gives him an incredulous look, Jingyi brushes it off and goes to open his suitcase. Jingyi and Sizhui spend the rest of the afternoon unpacking with the door between their rooms open and Jin Ling lording over them. By the time Jiang Yanli comes to announce dinner, all three of them are lying horizontally on Jingyi’s bed, watching videos on Jin Ling’s phone.
Dinner is extravagant as expected, with enough food to feed a small village. What’s more impressive is how many dishes now contain the loquats they’ve brought, ranging from fried to steamed to stewed. Jingyi’s mouth is already watering by the time he’s seated between Jin Ling and Sizhui, although he abruptly straightens up when Madam Yu’s gaze passes over him.
Sitting at the head of the table, under a pair of elaborate wall scrolls, is Jiang Fengmian. He looks incredibly mild next to his scowling wife, both of them instructing the staff on place settings. After some deliberation, Jiang Cheng takes the seat to Madam Yu’s right. Han Guang-Jun sits wordlessly on the other side of Jiang Fengmian while the twins are flanked by their parents. Jin Bing, in a power move that will probably never be mastered by her brother, appears at the last minutes and slides effortlessly into the only empty seat left. 
“Welcome to my home,” Jiang Fengmian begins when all the staff have stepped aside, “I apologize for seating us in the reserved dining area for now. Tomorrow we will dine in in the main hall.”
Jingyi almost chokes on his water. There’s another dining room even bigger than this? He recovers just in time, no thanks to Jin Ling swatting him unsympathetically on the back.
“It’s not everyday that we have the honor of hosting the Lan family,” Jiang Fengmian continues with a good humored smile. “My wife and I have been long time acquaintances of Lan Qiren. It’s my wish that he, too, will visit Lotus Pier.”
“Uncle would be honored,” is all Lan Wangji says. 
Whether Headmaster Lan would actually step foot in Yunmeng, no one will know. This doesn’t deter Jiang Fengmian. “It’s always a great blessing when I can be surrounded by my children and grandchildren, although A-Xian won’t be joining us until tomorrow.”
“We would have more grandchildren if Jiang Cheng and Wei Wuxian would hurry up and get married already,” Madam Yu cuts in, shooting a glare at her son. “Those two… All they do is run around with no regards to their responsibilities…”
The look of great consternation on Jiang Cheng’s face suggests this isn’t the first time he’s heard this rant. Regardless, he stays silent.
“Yu Ziyuan and I are very happy to be with the grandchildren we have now,” Jiang Fengmian adds, offering the kids a smile that’s met with a blush from Jin Ling, silence from Jin Bing, and vague noises from the twins who complain about wanting to eat already. This sends the Jiang head into a bemused laugh. “Well. Without further ado, let’s eat!”
The food is good. Really good. Jingyi doesn’t have time to offer compliments, too busy stuffing his face. He zones out on all the small talk and focuses on the slow turning of the glass top on the table as new dishes are presented before him. Jin Ling tsks at his behavior but still waves staff over to refill Jingyi’s teacup whenever it runs out. Soon, Jin Ling gets called away to fill the adults’ glasses with alcohol, and Sizhui is left with the sole duty of making sure Jingyi doesn’t choke himself to death on food.
“Does Lan Qiren even feed these kids at school?” Madam Yu huffs. “We can’t have him starving A-Ling in Gusu.”
“I’m fine,” Jin Ling insists, face red at the sudden attention. “Mom sends me lots of snacks and the food is okay. Dad and Xiaojiu all came out of it okay.”
“That’s questionable.”
Jiang Cheng looks like he has something to say, but he stops himself from participating in the conversation by putting more rice in his mouth. A cowardly tactic, if Jingyi has ever seen one.
“A-Ling is doing fine,” Jiang Yanli says while cutting the meat in Tiantian’s bowl into tiny pieces. Her husband seems to be less successful, since Qianqian keeps ordering her dad to do it better! This one is shaped weird! “He’s even grown a bit since starting school.”
Madam Yu narrows her eyes and beckons Jin Ling over to fuss over him. “Did you get taller? I’ll be the judge of that. Your dad has good genes, so you should be fine, but it doesn’t hurt for you to eat more.”
“T-thank you?” Jin Zixuan says, looking surprised by the sudden compliment, if one can call it that. While he’s not looking, Qianqian snatches the fried egg from his bowl and pops it in her mouth with quick work of her chopsticks. 
Dinner continues for hours, even after Jingyi had overeaten and driven himself into a pseudo-food coma. He’s half leaning on Sizhui’s side when staff members come out with the dessert they brought from Gusu. Everyone is served a piece on a delicate, lotus-shaped plate, but Jin Ling trades his with Jingyi when he decides he likes Jingyi’s better. 
It’s already late in the evening when everyone is dismissed from dinner. Jingyi barely remembers Jin Ling showing them where his room is. He splashes some water on his face and calls it a night. 
In the morning, Jingyi fumbles his way to the bathroom for a quick shower and discovers Sizhui is already awake. They chat idly about their non-existent plans while Sizhui tidies up.
“We should really ask Jin Ling what’s next,” Sizhui suggests.
Jingyi checks his phone to find it’s already 10am. “Jin Ling should be up. Let’s go.” He traces last night’s steps until arriving at the room that Jin Ling is staying in and abruptly throws the door open. “Little Mistress, are you up ye-”
“I told you not to call me that,” Jin Ling mumbles from his spot on the floor. Standing behind him is one of the twins, who’s busy brushing Jin Ling’s hair with a plastic toy. Behind her is the other twin, clipping bows into her sister’s hair. Behind both of them is Jiang Yanli, who patiently combs the girls’ hair out. Fairy lies lazily in front of Jin Ling, happily showing his belly as Jin Ling works on absently brushing him. It’s an incredible snapshot of domesticity.
“Good morning,” Jiang Yanli says when Jingyi fails to contain his laughter. She’s busy braiding one of the girl’s hair. “Have you boys had breakfast yet? There’s a spread laid out in the dining area from last night.”
“Thank you,” Sizhui says, just as one of the girls comes over to tug at him. She pushes Sizhui to sit on the floor next to Jin Ling and demands to do his hair too.
Jiang Yanli puts all the hair accessories back into a small box with the help of the other twin. “Don’t bother Lan-Gege, Qianqian. We’re almost done anyway. Don’t you want to go to the lake with Daddy? You made him promise to go with you and Tiantian.”
“I suppose,” Qianqian says importantly, as if deliberating a grave issue. Jingyi has a few ideas where she may have picked that up from. “Okay.”
It takes a while for the girls to pack up. They look offended when Jin Ling pulls a pink heart-shaped clip out of his hair and tries to hand it back, so Jin Ling is forced to wear it until his mother has led both girls out of the room. 
“Jin hair salon, huh?” Jingyi grins. 
“It was worse when they wanted to be chefs and tried to make me eat plastic food.”
Jingyi just cackles more. “What’s our plan for the day?”
“Food first.”
Together, the three of them make it to the dining area. Lan Wangji is already there, silently working on his congee, so they sit down next to him with their assortment of buns and soups. When asked, Lan Wangji admits he’s been invited by Jiang Fengmian to discuss business, which leaves the three of them with no chaperone and no supervision. 
After breakfast, Jin Ling takes them on a stroll through the marketplace at Lotus Pier. Merchants line both sides of the street as they blend into crowds of tourists. Jingyi is surprised to find that the shop fronts are all different, each promising a new Yunmeng speciality that he hasn’t seen before. For lunch, they have something light at one of the restaurants overlooking the water. The owner recognizes Jin Ling immediately and tries to give them food on the house, but Jin Ling settles the bill with a gold card that he pulls out of a tacky designer label wallet. 
Lotus Pier is bustling with noise from every corner, but it’s a fun kind of rowdiness that makes Jingyi thrum with excitement. He drags Jin Ling and Sizhui around by the arms as they sample all the street food and find suitable souvenirs for Jingyi’s parents. 
The sun is making its way towards the horizon when they finally wander back to the Jiang estate. They’re greeted by a strange scene in the East Wing courtyard, where the twins are crouched around a large tree. At the top, on a particularly thick branch, sits Wei Wuxian. He waves at the sight of them. 
“Ah! A-Yuan! Lingling! Little Lan!”
“Don’t call me that!” Jin Ling huffs the same time Jingyi shouts “My name is Lan Jingyi!” up into the tree.
Sizhui glances around. “What’s going on?”
“Dajiu brought us a kite and it’s stuck in a tree,” Tiantian says quietly, her eyes watering. “Xiaojiu went to find a ladder but Dajiu climbed up. He’s stuck.”
“I’m not stuck!” Wei Wuxian shouts down, one arm holding the offending kite. “I can come down at any point! In fact, I’ll do it right now!”
“You’re gonna break a leg!” Jin Ling hisses. “Just stay up there and wait for the ladder!”
If anything, this just spurns Wei Wuxian to move more. He drops the kite and laughs when Jin Ling leaps forward to catch it. “Don’t worry about me, Ling-zi! I can do it! You’re not strong enough to catch me anyway!”
“Just stay up there!” Jingyi snaps at him. “You’re way too high up!”
“Move aside! I’m seriously going to jump!”
“NO!” Jingyi and Jin Ling scream in synchrony. 
Thankfully, Lan Wangji appears then. He takes one look at the scene and seems to understand the situation. With a wave of his arm, he dismisses both Jin Ling and Jingyi. Even the girls step aside, hiding behind Sizhui. “Wei Ying. Don’t do anything rash.”
Wei Wuxian just laughs more. “Lan Zhan! What are you gonna do? You can’t stop me! Are you gonna catch me?”
A beat passes before Lan Wangji opens his arms. “I will.”
“Okay! Here I come!”
Multiple things happen at once: Sizhui steps in front of both girls and covers the view in case their uncle does break a leg, Jingyi grabs Jin Ling’s arm in a moment of suspense, and Wei Wuxian leaps down from the branch without a worry. Wei Wuxian’s movement is followed by the sound of fluttering fabric as Lan Wangji manages to grab ahold of him, his whole body twisting from the momentum until Lan Wangji turns around, both of his arms wrapped around Wei Wuxian in an incredible bridal carry that reminds Jingyi of clutch saves in wuxia films. 
Even more incredible is the fact that Wei Wuxian makes no effort to part from Lan Wangji’s embrace. “Lan Zhan! You’re so strong!”
“Strong!” Qianqian says, making grabby hands up. “I want to be picked up too! Up up!”
“Lan-shushu is busy picking me up. You gotta wait your turn!”
Qianqian looks like she wants to argue, but Jiang Cheng appears then with the aforementioned ladder. She runs right to him, tugging at Jiang Cheng’s arm until he crouches down to listen. Jiang Cheng’s eyes narrow slowly as he takes in the scene. He glares at Wei Wuxian, who is still in Lan Wangji’s arms. “I was gone for ten minutes.”
The only response he gets is an absent wave of Wei Wuxian’s hand. “You took too long, and now you can’t play the hero!”
Jiang Cheng looks like he has some words for Wei Wuxian that he can’t say in front of the kids, so he just tsks loudly. He’s starting to leave with the ladder when Jin Zixuan appears, prompting both girls to fly to his side. 
To his credit, Jin Zixuan doesn’t even ask what’s going on, like he can’t be bothered to comprehend Wei Wuxian’s shenanigans. “I came to tell you all that dinner is ready. Han Guang-Jun, you may want to put my brother-in-law down.”
“Looks like you have to let me go. We don’t want people to get the wrong idea, Lan Er Gege~.”
What wrong idea?! Jingyi wants to scream. People can only get the RIGHT idea!
Still, everyone is presentable by the time they arrive at the main dining room. If possible, the food spread is even larger today. Everyone settles into a familiar seating arrangement, with the addition of Wei Wuxian at Lan Wangji’s side. Today, they’re saved from a speech and allowed to dig in immediately. Jingyi is amazed to find that not a single dish from last night’s feast has been repeated.
“Lan Zhan, you gotta try this. It’s my favorite!” Wei Wuxian say while picking food from a few dishes up with his chopsticks and setting them in Lan Wangji’s bowl.
Jingyi’s eyes nearly fall out of their sockets at the sight. Almost everything is covered with chilli powder to the point where the food is indistinguishable. “Are you trying to kill Han Guang-Jun?!”
Wei Wuxian pauses. “What? Lan Zhan loves spicy food!”
“Actually,” Sizhui says helpfully. “Father’s palette is quite bland.”
“Really? But he used to always orders spicy food when we ate together. I thought we had the same taste… Lan Zhan, your appetite really dulled through the years!” He looks to the other adults for agreement, but Jiang Cheng just rolls his eyes.
Lan Wangji doesn't respond. Instead, he valiantly puts a chilli-covered piece of meat into his mouth and swallows it whole. 
“That’s one way of doing it,” Jin Zixuan mumbles, his own bowl devoid of red colored items. He gives Lan Wangji a sympathetic look and goes back to picking soft food for his daughter.
The Emperor’s Smile comes out soon after that, and Wei Wuxian’s entire face light up at the sight of the jars. He beckons Jin Ling over to pour for him, which ends in a round of toasts with all the men of the family. 
When Lan Wangji shakes his head at Jin Ling, Madam Yu speaks up. “Han Guang-Jun? Aren’t you going to drink with us? You didn’t touch the wine at all yesterday. Surely, if you don’t like Emperor’s Smile, then we can find you something else from my husband’s collection.”
Lan Wangji stares resolutely at his cup and reaches for it. He’s foiled, however, when Wei Wuxian snatches the cup and downs the liquor. 
Next to Jingyi, Sizhui lets out a small breath of relief. 
“Lan Zhan has really bad alcohol tolerance! I’ll drink for him!” Wei Wuxian offers. “I can handle both of our shares and still outdrink Jiang Cheng and Jin Zixuan!”
“A-Xian,” Jiang Fengmian says. “It’s not a competition.”
“Besides! Lan Zhan is such an angry drunk! The last time we drank together, he stuck to my side the entire time! I couldn’t shake him off at all because he was so mad at me, haha! Let’s not offend Han Guang-Jun with our drinking habits!”
Everyone is quiet, staring Wei Wuxian in disbelief. 
“Let’s not pressure Han Guang-Jun,” Jiang Yanli suggests, an unreadable smile on her face. “Besides, you should also hold off on the alcohol, Father. It’s bad for your blood pressure. Why don’t you have some lotus rib soup? I helped Chef Wang prepare it.” 
While everyone is served a bowl of soup, Madam Yu turns to Wei Wuxian. “It’s best if you stop bothering Han Guang-Jun. He’s too polite to say otherwise, but I’m sure Han Guang-Jun is only tolerating your overly familiar behavior.”
Wei Wuxian’s smile wavers. He straightens himself up and moves away from Lan Wangji when the man in question stops him. 
“Wei Ying does not bother me. I enjoy his company.” A moment of silence passes over them as every member of the family stares at Lan Wangji. Still, his passive expression remains the same, unmovable as always.
Eventually, Madam Yu lets out of a bark of laughter. It’s equal parts incredulous and amused. “If that’s the way it is, then suit yourself.”
Later, when dinner is finished and everyone is dismissed, Jin Ling confesses this is the closest thing to approval he has heard from his grandmother. 
“At least she approves of this marriage,” Jingyi mumbles, remembering how Wei Wuxian had downed alcohol like water and walked away from it all unfazed. Jin Zixuan had called it quits early, saying he needed to help the girls get ready for bed. It was a cowardly escape, leaving Jiang Cheng to drink against Wei Wuxian. By the time dessert was finished, Jiang Cheng was busy flicking open peanut casings and sunflower seeds and Wei Wuxian while Wei Wuxian draped himself over Lan Wangji. Madam Yu herself had gone cup to cup against Wei Wuxian before bowing out, to the great amusement and concern of her husband. Really, the entire Jiang family was intent on showing each other up in strange ways that Jingyi cannot begin to comprehend. “Hey. Maybe Wei Wuxian and Han Guang-Jun will drunkenly hook up.”
Jin Ling makes a disgusted face. “Ew. Don’t think about that.”
To Jingyi’s disappointment, Han Guang-Jun and Wei Wuxian do not drunkenly hook up that night. Jingyi knows because he gives himself the task of camping behind a bush outside of Wei Wuxian’s quarters, just to catch a glimpse of Jin Ling’s uncle retiring for the night. If they’re lucky, Wei Wuxian would drag a compliant Lan Wangji in with him! Unfortunately, Jingyi’s luck has always been rotten, and he finds himself getting a cramp from crouching for so long. It’s a good thing he didn’t invite Sizhui and Jin Ling along, both of them too indignant for such an important task like espionage. 
“Urg,” Jingyi hisses when his phone runs out of battery. “Where are you?”
“Where’s who?” A voice asks, and Jingyi falls on his butt at the surprise. Wei Wuxian grins back at him, also squatting behind the same bush. “Who are we spying on?”
You! Jingyi thinks but bites his lips from saying. He sits up, crossed legged. “N-nothing! I just heard …That... That this area of the house is haunted. I wanted to see the ghost with my own eyes.”
“Where’s A-Yuan and Ling’er?”
Jingyi tries to feign annoyance. “Sizhui doesn’t believe in ghosts and Jin Ling went to sleep already.”
“I see. They have no appreciation for the wonderful world of the occult!” They’re both crouched on the grass with nothing but the courtyard lanterns illuminating the area, yet Wei Wuxian’s grin is unbearably bright. “Why don’t you go hunting with me?”
“Hunting? For what?”
Wei Wuxian shoots up, grabbing Jingyi’s arm in the process. “Ghosts, of course! Let’s go!” He effortlessly drags a fumbling Jingyi out of the courtyard and through a series of walkways. They encounter a few members of the nightstaff on the way, but for the most part, the estate is silent and peaceful if not for Jingyi’s sputtering. 
“Where are you taking me?” Jingyi demands.
“The most haunted part of this place!” Wei Wuxian replies cheerfully. He then proceeds show Jingyi a series of baffling locations in the estate: a well where a servant was apparently pushed in by a jealous lover, Madam Yu’s favorite gazebo which allegedly lights up red with the blood of all who’s drowned in the waters but really just feels like a peaceful date location, and an abandoned broom closet where Jiang Cheng found dead rats years ago. Not once do they encounter a ghost, but Wei Wuxian still makes Jingyi keep him company as they sit near the docks. “And that’s how the corpse head of the general came to be buried under the house, and why he comes out to haunt us every spring.”
Jingyi swats at another fly that has managed to land on his leg. He’s been scratching a particular spot on his ankle for while. “That sounds fake, like one of those period dramas. How are these bugs not biting you?”
Wei Wuxian drops a small tube on Jingyi’s lap. “Use this! It’ll help. And anyways, I didn’t steal it from a drama. I actually read it in one of Bingbing’s webnovels!” 
Jingyi squints at the tiny pack. “What is this? Toothpaste? You don’t have real bug cream? Aren’t you a doctor?”
“Sometimes you gotta improvise! I guess you’d rather get eaten alive instead~?”
“Ack! Gimme that.” Jingyi smoothes a dollop of minty toothpaste on his existing bites and frowns. “How come none of the bugs are biting you? Is your skin too thick?”
Wei Wuxian laughs. “They’ve had enough of me! You’re the newcomer here with your exotic blood~ All the mosquitoes are clambering to get some of that Lan juice. You’re all so plump and pure and sweet.”
“I’m not a peach ripe for the picking,” Jingyi mumbles. “You’re so weird… I don’t know why Han Guang-Jun likes you.”
In an act that truly infuriates Jingyi, Wei Wuxian has the audacity to tilt his head in confusion. “Lan Zhan doesn’t like me! He just tolerates me because he’s so polite and patient.”
Jingyi kind of wants to push Wei Wuxian into the water, but killing one halves of the pair he’s trying to matchmake would be counter intuitive to his plans. Plus, Jin Ling would probably throw a fuss. Jingyi thinks about what Sizhui would do, and tries to reason with him. “Why would you think Han Guang-Jun doesn’t like you? He spends the most time with you.”
“Lan Zhan just goes along with my whims because it’s easier than the hassle of rejecting me,” Wei Wuxian replies, completely serious. The smile on his face does slip a little, and Jingyi kind of regrets offering to play therapist to someone with the emotional comprehension of a rock. This guy is even more hard-headed than a piece of white rabbit candy that’s been sitting around for too long. 
“Urg,” Jingyi grumbles at last. “Whatever. I want to go to sleep already.”
“You’re not gonna wait for the ghost head to appear? How lame.” Still, Wei Wuxian cheerfully stands up and leads Jingyi towards the living quarters. 
The walk back is smoother, calmer, as they’re accompanied by the distant chirping of crickets. Lotus Pier really is beautifully peaceful, with well tended gardens and ponds at every turn. Jingyi thinks it must be so idyllic to grow up here. They’re almost in the East Wing when a familiar bark startles Wei Wuxian, and Jingyi turns around to find Fairy happily wagging his tail near a tree. Next to him is Jiang Cheng, looking bored, while Jin Bing sits a few steps away on the stone steps leading up to the rooms. 
“J-j-jiang Cheng! What are you doing? What is that beast doing?!” Wei Wuxian very obviously steps behind Jingyi. 
Jin Bing barely looks up from the glow of her phone screen. “Fairy was getting restless and had to pee. I took him out here and ran into Xiaojiu.”
“My dog senses were tingling,” Jiang Cheng says seriously as he sits on the stone walkway and plays with Fairy. He seems notably happier to be ruffling Fairy, the look of constant irritation having melted off his face. “What are you doing out here? Are you hazing A-Ling’s little friend?”
“My name is Lan Jingyi!”
“The adults are talking, Lan Jingyi,” Jiang Cheng says. He doesn’t look very intimidating with Fairy licking his jaw. 
Well, Jingyi thinks. Wei Wuxian hardly feels like an adult with the way he’s trembling behind him. “I’m leaving now!” Jingyi declares, if only to have an excuse for Wei Wuxian to retreat and lead Jingyi back. Wei Wuxian takes the bait immediately and latches onto Jingyi’s arm, practically dragging him out of the area.
Still, this gives Jingyi an idea.
The next morning, Jingyi drags his tired body out of bed when Sizhui finally comes knocking on their shared door. It’s National Day, and they find a modest assortment of breakfast laid out in the main living room as the Jiang family scatters around the large low table, watching the Beijing National Parade on the large television. Jingyi takes a strip of youtiao and a cup of soy milk. He takes a seat next to Jin Ling, who makes room and grabs two extra floor cushions for them.
“Don’t eat too much,” Jiang Yanli reminds them while blowing gently on the congee in Tiantian’s bowl. “Remember, we’re going out for lunch.”
The parade is pretty typical and anticlimactic. Madam Yu and Jiang Fengmian discuss the unnecessary opulence of it all while Wei Wuxian makes weird commentary that everyone but Lan Wangji ignores. Everyone has various level of interest in the show-- the twins are amazed by the army drill formations, Jiang Cheng comments idly about terrible Beijing traffic, and Jin Bing just stares at her phone screen through the entire televised program. 
After the National Parade ends, Madam Yu makes a thinly veiled comment demanding everyone change into proper attire for lunch. Jingyi looks down at his shirt and pajama pants and gulps when he feels the heat of her disapproval.
An hour later, everyone gathers at the main gate. Jingyi, having been bullied by Jin Ling into changing into something more formal, is rolling up the sleeves of his button-up shirt when three separate cars come to chauffeur them into the center of Lotus Pier. There, the entire family step into a three story restaurant already crowded with patrons. They’ve booked the entire third floor, which has an open air balcony that overlooks into the busy merchant streets. 
“Grandpa owns this restaurant,” Jin Ling explains when Jingyi’s jaw drops at the sight. “We have lunch here every year and stay through the Lotus Pier parade.”
Wei Wuxian manages to wiggle his way over with Lan Wangji in tow. “The Lotus Pier parade is organized by locals. We never know what they’re gonna include. Last year, there was a blown up balloon of Uncle Jiang whic-” He coughs abruptly. “Which we all agreed was a poor and rude caricature, and not funny in any way. Nope. Maybe this year they’ll do one of our Master Jin~”
“Not a chance,” Jin Zixuan says wryly. “I’m not a local favorite. If anything, I’d say you or Jiang Cheng are up next.”
“If it was Jiang Cheng, his balloon head would pop from anger!”
“I’m about to pop your head,” Jiang Cheng hisses. Next to him, Madam Yu and Jiang Fengmian very obviously ignore this entire conversation.
Jiang Yanli touches her husband’s arm, her smile devious. “What about me, Darling? Do I not warrant a balloon figure too?”
This stuns Jin Zixuan for a moment before he says, “A-Li. A balloon will never be able to capture how lovely you are. There’s simply no comparison.” His comment sends half the table into embarrassed groans, but the most embarrassing part is how genuine he sounds. Jin Zixuan looks even more pleased when this reply earns soft laughter from Jiang Yanli.
“How sweet,” Jingyi tells Jin Ling. “Your parents are still so in love after four kids.”
“Yeah, but we all know the twins were an accident,” Wei Wuxian whispers, then yelps when Jiang Cheng slaps him on the arm. His comment was quiet enough that everyone either did not hear or chose to ignore him. Still, Wei Wuxian is shameless as always. “Lan Zhan! Protect me from this brute!”
Lan Wangji responds by carefully rubbing at the spot Jiang Cheng slapped Wei Wuxian. 
Jingyi is immediately distracted by the food after that. The nightly feasts at the Jiang estate feel almost like child’s play compared to the quantity of dishes served this time around. Ducks and fish and beef and pork and lamb, all prepared in a variety of ways that make Jingyi wish he could become one with the table. Jingyi doesn’t know how he can go back to Cloud Recesses after being spoiled in Yunmeng. Maybe he should be the one marrying into this family, if their beloved Han Guang-Jun fails.
Speaking of Han Guang-Jun-- Jingyi turns around to find Wei Wuxian putting dishes into Lan Wangji’s bowl again. This time, the items are only sprinkled with a hint of red. Jingyi kind of wants to scream. How can Wei Wuxian turn a blind eye to their dynamics when they’re already acting like a married couple? How can someone who’s allegedly brilliant in his field be so dense? Is this fun for him? 
“Chew your food,” Jin Ling reminds him. “Breathe. Stop acting like an animal.”
Jingyi sneezes then and almost spits food from his mouth onto Jin Ling’s face. He’s only saved from public disgrace when Sizhui shoves a cloth napkin in front of Jingyi’s mouth at the last minute. 
“I’m never taking you home again,” Jin Ling hisses, turning a piece of eggplant over in his bowl. “All you do is embarass me.”
“Spoken like a true little princess,” Jingyi says, then makes a noise of complaint when Jin Ling shoves a tiny fried mantou into Jingyi’s mouth to shut him up. 
Lunch proceeds like any other large meal. The younger kids are restless by the end, causing Jin Zixuan to pick Tiantian up and take her to the balcony to people watch. Qianqian ends up climbing into the seat next to Sizhui, babbling to him about a story she made up about little carrot people. The owner of the restaurant keeps sending complimentary bottles of alcohol up, and Jiang Fengmian leaves to speak with him and all the other tourists itching to get a glimpse of the Lotus Pier patriarch. 
When the eating comes to a lull, Jin Bing pulls out her iPad. Jingyi, Sizhui, and Jin Ling take a go at her rhythm games and try to cheat the system by having all three of them tap on the screen at the same time. They come nowhere near Jin Bing’s original score, despite Jingyi’s best attempt at poking at random dots on the screen. Jin Bing then opens a puzzle game, but Jingyi and Jin Ling’s team loses terribly to Sizhui and Jin Bing’s team.
“Clearly we are the superior Lan-Jin combo,” Jin Bing says, which makes Jingyi challenge her to a rematch. He doesn’t get his wish because a loud horn signals the beginning of the parade below them. 
Some shuffling ensues as the twins squeeze themselves to the front, held carefully up by a grandparent each so they can see over the balcony. A quick glance below shows that the rest of the street-facing stores are all filled with people lined up at the front to witness the show. 
The sound of distant drumming arrives first as they catch sight of the lion dancers. An ornately crafted lion head jiggles and preens and drops its mouth as the first lion dancers move around the streets to the excited cheers of the audience.
“Lan Zhan, did you know? It’s an honor to be the lion dancers opening the parade! Jiang Cheng and I fought for days about who got to be the head the year we turned eighteen! I won, of course-”
“Only because you got lucky at rock paper scissors!”
“Pay attention!” Madam Yu chides, effectively silencing them both.
Two more sets of lions appear, prancing and jumping and performing stunts. It’s pretty impressive, now that Jingyi knows that the dancers change on a yearly basis and are selected by the parade committee out of all the youths in the area. 
Then comes 24 drums performers, causing the younger kids to vibrate exciting to the beat of the music. Huh, Jingyi thinks, the budget for this must be pretty high.
The drummers are followed by folk dancers, the signature dragon dances looping through the streets in golden glory. A group of aunties soon follow, with their long sleeves waving to the sound of folk music. The audience seems delighted, as more and more people appear, crowded on top of each other at storefronts. 
Soon, a group of kids dressed in purple appear with detailed fans. They move messily, but endearingly, to the choreography until all the kids are called back to the center. All of them stretch on cue, their extended fans forming the undeniable shape of a nine-petal lotus.
“How quaint,” Madam Yu says, sounding pleased. 
“Did you ever participate in this?” Sizhui asks Jin Ling.
Wei Wuxian pokes his head over. “He sure did! And I sure have pictures!”
“No! Stop it! Pay attention!” Jin Ling demands, face flushed.
The procession of balloons are next. Thankfully, there is no caricature head of the Jiang family this time. However, the giant inflated pig is very obviously wearing a qipao with lotus designs. Jingyi is torn between laughing and crying when the pig winks. 
“We need to consider limiting the funds to this,” Madam Yu says. “This is getting ridiculous.”
Jiang Fengmian laughs in amusement, with Qianqian in his arms. “Oh, San-Niang, but I’m enjoying this.”
At the very end of the parade are people dressed up as famous characters like the cast of Journey to the West. However, it’s not until they get closer that Jiang Cheng very obviously says, “Oh, no.”
Below, someone very obviously dressed as Jiang Fengmian seems to be reacting a skit with another person in red. There’s fake weapons, fake shoutings, and a fake fight scene choreographed until the man in red fake collapses. 
“Oh my God,” Wei Wuxian is laughing so hard he’s crying now. “Is that supposed to be Wen Rouhan?”
Below them, a maiden wearing purple appears and swoons at the sight of fake Jiang Fengmian. 
“I’m going to have a serious talk with Organizer Fei,” Madam Yu decides while her family bursts into hysterics. Even Jiang Yanli has to hide her laughter in her husband’s shoulder.
On the streets, fake Madam Yu has to be carried bridal style by her fake husband to loud cheers.
“This parade gets better and better every year,” Wei Wuxian tells a passive looking Lan Wangji. “Wasn’t it great? Didn’t you like it, Lan Zhan?”
Lan Wangji says, “I would’ve liked to see you as a lion dancer.”
Wei Wuxian grins immediately. “Oh! I was only the head, you know! According to locals, Jiang Cheng is the one with the better ass!”
“If Jiang Cheng finally kills Wei Wuxian,” Jin Zixuan tells his wife quietly while Jiang Cheng reaches for Wei Wuxian with murderous intent, stopped only by Wei Wuxian hiding behind Lan Wangji. “It will be what he deserves.”
While Jiang Cheng’s attempt to eradicate his brother goes on in the background to the annoyance of Madam Yu and the giggling delight of the twins, Sizhui regroups with Jingyi and Jin Ling. “Isn’t Dr. Wei already so close to my Father? I don’t know what to do at this point for him to get a clue.”
“Oh,” Jingyi says, remembering last night. “I have an idea!”
Jin Ling is pretty sure that all of Jingyi’s plans will always, inevitably, lead them somewhere ridiculous. In this case, it’s with Jin Ling squatting behind a wall as Sizhui and Jingyi position themselves inconspicuously around him, all three of them watching Wei Wuxian speak to Lan Wangji in Grandma Yu’s favorite pagoda on the water. They’re far enough that Jin Ling can’t read his uncle’s lips, much less hear the conversation. “This is a waste of time,” Jin Ling hisses.
“Patience,” Jingyi replies while holding Fairy in his arms. Fairy looks excited to be included in their plans and proceeds to lick Jingyi’s chin. “We need to wait for the most opportune time.”
In the distance, Wei Wuxian sets a hand on Lan Wangji’s arm as he laughs. Lan Wangji looks back at Wei Wuxian silently, comfortably. They exude an air of an old married couple, much like Jin Ling’s parents whenever they get a moment of reprieve from the kids. Not for the first time, Jin Ling wonders if they even need to be here, butting into his uncle’s business.
“Maybe we should call this off,” Sizhui says, voicing Jin Ling’s concerns. “I don’t think it’s a good idea to bother them, and Dr. Wei really seems to be frightened of dogs.”
Jingyi waves him off with the arm Fairy isn’t currently drooling over. “He needs to get over his phobia anyway. It’s weird to be scared of dogs.”
“You were scared of the cockroach in the dorm,” Jin Ling points out, irate. 
“That thing was coming for my life!” Jingyi snaps. He then goes on to retell the story of a fist-sized cockroach crawling into his stall in the dorm bathroom, all of which Jin Ling has heard more than once with varying degrees of over-exaggeration. 
Jin Ling is distracted from Jingyi’s ridiculous storytelling when a small fist pulls at the sleeve of his shirt, and Jin Ling looks down to find big, brown eyes peering up at him. He hadn’t heard the girls sneak up on them at all, but Qianqian and Tiantian now stand in front of him, blocking his view of the pagoda. They’re much more independent than Jin Ling had been at their age. Not that Jin Ling remembers much except the incident about him throwing a fit over a lost balloon that no one in his family will let him forget.
“Gege,” Qianqian says, opening her arms wide as if expecting a hug. “Up up.”
Jin Ling sets a hand on her head. “No. You heard Laolao. You’re too old to be picked up now.”
“Lan-Gege is holding Fairy,” Tiantian says quietly, pointing a tiny accusatory finger at Jingyi. 
Jin Ling doesn’t know how to explain that Jingyi is only holding onto Fairy to stop him from interrupting the next stage of their plan. “That’s different.”
Qianqian blows her cheeks up like a goldfish. “It’s not.”
“It is,” Jin Ling insists, even though he already knows he’s on the losing side of this conversation. His gaze lands back on the pagoda. “Come on, get out of the way.”
“Wanna play?”
“We’re busy. You can’t play with the big kids. Go find Bingbing or something.”
“So you admit you’re a kid, but just bigger?” Jingyi points out with a laugh. “And you’re barely older than Bingbing! Why are you acting all high and mighty?”
“Um-” Sizhui says but is cut off by Jin Ling’s tsk.
“I’m way older!” Two whole years are nothing to scoff over, even if they’re almost the same height now. Not that Jin Ling has a complex about it or anything!
“The girls-” Sizhui coughs. “They left.”
Sure enough, Tiantian and Qianqian have wandered off hand in hand towards the water. Jin Ling watches, jaw slack, as his sisters interrupt Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji, no doubt asking to be picked up again.
“We should’ve just done what they asked,” Jingyi mumbles as they watch the girls tug on Wei Wuxian’s pants.
Wei Wuxian, like the rest of Jin Ling’s family, has probably been given Grandma Yu’s decree about not caving to the twins’ demands. Jin Ling personally thinks she’s being too hard on them. Jin Ling himself had gotten piggyback rides from his uncles even after entering primary school, not that he’d admit any of this aloud. 
Still, Jin Ling watches as Qianqian turns her pleading eyes on Sizhui’s father. He’s shocked when Lan Wangji effortlessly picks up a girl in each arm, like they’re Sizhui’s rabbits instead of little bundles of energy that kicked and screamed after missing a nap. 
“Han Guang-Jun really knows how to turn on the charm, huh?” Jingyi says while Wei Wuxian obviously beams. “He’s really working that hot single father angle.”

“Weddings are occasions for family and friends! How could you even consider forgoing it?!” Madam Yu had hollered at Wei Wuxian during the following family gathering. Then she’d decided that an elaborate reception was necessary. Jin Ling was pretty sure Wei Wuxian had only agreed because Madam Yu insisted on planning it to the last detail, leaving Wei Wuxian with no responsibility whatsoever except to keep his marriage alive until then. 
Jin Ling supposes that part isn’t hard, what with the way Wei Wuxian is currently laughing into Lan Wangji’s neck as the two of them greet guests hand in hand. Jin Ling wrinkles his nose. Gross. 
“A-Ling,” Jiang Yanli says, appearing out of nowhere. “There are more guests.”
Sure enough, Lan Xichen is now at the door, politely depositing a red envelope into the box. Sizhui has beaten Jin Ling there as he greets his uncle. Well, also Jin Ling’s uncle now. His uncle-in-law? Jin Ling’s head hurts just thinking about it. He follows his mother to the door.
“Ze Wu-Jun!” Jingyi is present too, dressed in something probably too casual. He’d spent the last few hours lounging around until Headmaster Lan had ordered him to help Sizhui and Jin Ling. “Long time no see!”
Lan Xichen smiles. It’s weird for Jin Ling to think this is what Lan Wangji would probably look like if he could express emotions on command. “Sizhui, Jingyi-- it’s nice to see you again. Madam Jiang-- It’s always a pleasure.”
Jiang Yanli laughs softly. “There’s no need to be so formal. I’d say we’re already so close, but now we are actually one family. You already know A-Ling.”
“Good evening,” Jin Ling says stiffly, and glares when Jingyi snickers at his formal behavior. 
The happy couple chooses then to join the conversation, Wei Wuxian’s arm still looped through Lan Wangji’s as people mingle around them. Wei Wuxian looks much brighter these days. He’s always been a bit of a people pleaser and played the role fit for someone used to being the center of attention, but nowadays Jin Ling’s wayward uncle looks happy and complacent just simply existing in Lan Wangji’s orbit.
“Brother,” Lan Wangji says softly while Wei Wuxian goes on a long winded greeting for his brother-in-law, recollecting some event or another from their shared past.
Jin Ling zones out for most of it until his mother taps his shoulder. “A-Ling, please take Ze Wu-Jun to his seat.”
“This way,” Jin Ling says as both Lan Xichen and Sizhui follow. He only gets halfway across the room before Lan Xichen halts at the sight of familiar faces. Jin Ling should be annoyed, but he’s somewhat intrigued when Sizhui makes a soft noise of embarrassment. Together, they trail after the man to the errand table. 
Lan Xichen is all smiles as he speaks to Sizhui’s relatives? Cousins? Second Aunt twice removed? “Long time no see, Dr. Wen. Nurse Wen.”
Wen Qing seems completely unmoved by Lan Xichen’s charms, a complete contrast to the man next her who looks flustered. “I’d say the honor is all mine. It’s no surprise to see you here.”
“It’s not everyday I get to celebrate my younger brother’s marriage.”
“Is that so? You should tell your brother that,” Wen Qing replies smoothly, nursing a cup of tea. “He sure likes to appear at the hospital and obstruct our work everyday.”
 “Jie! I think it’s sweet that Han Guang-Jun visits Dr. Wei and brings him lunch every day! I, um, think it’s also good for the nurses’ morales. And you were so thankful for Ze Wu-Jun’s presence the last time we went drinking with Dr. Wei and Han Guang-Jun.”
Jin Ling raises his eyebrows while Sizhui flushes at the obvious start of another incriminating story about his father.
“It’s not my fault Lan Wangji is such a lightweight,” Wen Qing says primly. “Wei Wuxian would’ve been able to take his perfect husband home by himself if Lan Wangji wasn’t busy making a drunken scene.” She pauses, then says something surprising. “Marriage is good for them.”
Lan Xichen just smiles in agreement. His eternally pleasant expression doesn’t change even when Jin Ling’s grandmother arrives at the table, her face stern as always. She gives Lan Xichen and Sizhui’s relatives curt greetings while lamenting Wei Wuxian’s inability to entertain the guests. 
“Dr. Wei seems busy,” Wen Ning suggests helpfully and receives a scrutinizing look from Madam Yu for it. 
“Han Guang-Jun is too obliging,” Madam Yu says. “And to think Wei Wuxian was able to secure such a wonderful match while Jiang Cheng is still tragically single-”
Jiang Cheng sneezes loudly from across the room, where he is speaking to people who look too stuffy to be anyone but business associates. Bingbing, dutifully playing the role of the perfect Jin Heiress, hands him a tissue.
“I’m sure Wangji’s affections for Dr. Wei is not limited to his family background, however excellent they are…” Lan Xichen replies.
“Yes, yes, your brother has no shortage of praise for his Wei Ying. It’s a wonder they ever lived without each other, with the way they’re now attached at the hips. I haven’t seen anything as sickenly sweet since Zixuan begged A-Li to marry him. ” Madam Yu makes a dismissive hand wave, but her pleased expression belies her ire. “Ze Wu-Jun, let me escort you to your table. We have much to discuss.” Then she walks off with a hand set firmly on Lan Xichen’s arm-- an act that Jin Ling always thought was an endearing habit from his mom that he now recognizes as a power move passed down in his family. 
Sizhui just gives Jin Ling a sheepish smile. It’s an expression he’s adopted a lot since his father threw all caution to the wind and began engaging in gross amounts of PDA with Jin Ling’s uncle. “Shall we go back?”
“Work hard, A-Yuan,” Wen Ning says when Jin Ling and Sizhui head back to the entrance. 
The man currently chatting with Wei Wuxian at the front is vaguely familiar looking. Jin Ling has to do a double take when he recognizes Nie Huaisang, someone he has always associated with his dad’s side of the family. This converging of people of interests is starting to give Jin Ling a headache. He’s just glad his father is away on a business trip and the twins are too busy being preoccupied and babysat by the endless stream of relatives present.
Nie Huaisang is currently accompanied by a woman in pink who looks less like a date and more like a handler. She looks amused at the way Jingyi is currently gaping at her.
“Ling’er! A-Yuan!” Wei Wuxian beams. Somehow, he’s still hanging off Lan Wangji’s arm. “Come meet my old classmates! I haven’t seen them in forever! Huaisang, I still can’t believe you ran into Mianmian!”
“Yes, it was quite a coincidence.” The woman, the legend, baidu user m1@n_2 smiles back at them. “I’m sorry for crashing your reception unannounced.”
Wei Wuxian grabs her hand. “Don’t be silly! Of course you’re welcome! And to think most of our original hiking group are all here! Who’d thought Lan Zhan and I would end up together? I seriously thought he would kill me out of annoyance when we got stuck in that cave together, hahaa!” 
“Yes,” Mianmian says. “What a surprise.”
Jin Ling has to clench his jaw shut to stop himself from calling out the obvious lie. From the looks of things, Jingyi is struggling equally hard as he tries to hide behind Sizhui. 
“Your kids are quite handsome,” Mianmian adds, apropos to nothing.
Wei Wuxian just grins. “Lingling gets all of his good genes from me, of course~ Sizhui is Lan Zhan’s baby bun. He takes after the handsome Han Guang-Jun.”
“Mn,” Lan Wangji replies passively. No one bothers to point out that neither Jin Ling nor Sizhui are genetically related to either of them.
“And this is their friend, Lan Jingyi~”
Nie Huaisang chooses then to unfold his handheld fan and hide his obvious laughter behind it. The amused look Mianmian is sending Jingyi also makes sense, for Lan Jingyi is the only idiot who would use a real photo of himself holding a drumstick as his baidu icon. 
“It’s nice to have friends,” Nie Huaisang says cryptically. “Friends who look out for you, watch your back, and investigate your personal life through the internet.” He levels a particular look at Jin Ling.
Wei Wuxian blinks while Lan Wangji gives the Lan boys a searching look. “What?”
“What?” Nie Huaisang echoes the question back, feigning innocence. 
“What do you mean?”
Nie Huaisang closes his fan. “Oh, ignore me. I was just lost in thought. Now please excuse me. I must find Jiang-Xiong. I believe he owes me some money.” He heads for the other end of the room with Mianmian in tow.
Both of them are barely out of earshot when Jingyi bursts out laughing. He runs out of breath and has to use Sizhui as an anchor while Jin Ling does his best to stare through the ceiling.
“For the record,” Wei Wuxian says. “I know the three of you are up to something. I’m just choosing to ignore it. Oh, there’s my coworker. I gotta go talk to her!”
Lan Wangji waits until Wei Wuxian has run off to turn to them. “Say nothing to Wei Ying,” he warns them placidly, which now explains his willful participation in their matchmaking schemes.
Sizhui just hums as he watches his father leave. “I guess we really weren’t the first people who tried to set them up.”
Across the room, Wei Wuxian is laughing as Lan Wangji wraps an arm around his waist. Wei Wuxian beams up with unbridled happiness. It’s a little gross and a little sweet. Jin Ling sincerely hopes that the two of them will never drift again so they can be the last people to bring them together.
